items: Train systematic thinking: use the “Problem → Audience → Solution → Validation” framework to move from vague to clear.
Reduce blind attempts: list hypotheses and risks in advance to focus on validating critical unknowns.
Improve collaboration efficiency: adopt a unified output format for easier team discussion and iteration.
Combine multiple AI tools: leverage each tool’s strengths to balance ideation, data, and feasibility.

blocks.title: Self-Discovery (Identity & Preferences)
blocks.content:
You are a **structured career coach**. Guide me with a “few questions per turn and wait for my reply” approach to perform a self-inventory.
At most 3 questions per round; the next round must follow up based on my previous answers.

blocks.title: Habit Building (Smallest Unit)
blocks.content:
You are a **behavior design coach**. Based on my goal, design “micro-habits”:
- Trigger → Behavior (≤2 minutes) → Immediate feedback
- Failure pre-plan (If … then …)
- 7-day tracker (checkable)
- Nightly reflection 3Qs: What did I do today? What was hard? How will I tweak tomorrow?
Use this flow to turn inspiration into a testable mini-experiment (MVP).

items: **Define the problem**: list user contexts, blockers, alternatives, and the cost of not solving it.
**Specify the audience**: write the ICP (age/role/context) and clarify whether decision-maker and user are the same.
**Unique solution**: describe the differentiators (speed/cost/experience/accuracy) and avoid vague terms.
**MVP design**: minimal features (≤3), data flow, success/failure signals.
**Validation metrics**: problem–solution fit (interviews), early retention (W2), conversion rate.
**Risk map**: market/tech/cost/privacy/habit, with mitigation for each.

items: Converge: jot down 3 recurring frictions or observed problems.
Diverge: use the Five Pathways to generate 2–3 ideas each.
Rank: score by impact × feasibility using the matrix below.
Smallest experiment: pick top 1 and design an MVP finishable within 3 days.
Validate & iterate: collect data, keep validated hypotheses, drop invalid ones.

blocks.title: Scoring dimensions (1–5 points; 5 is best)
rows: Is the problem frequent and painful?
How do users solve it today? At what cost?
Can we build an MVP in 2–4 weeks?
Is there a clear and perceivable advantage?
Are there clear, low-cost channels to reach users?
Can it produce ongoing value and revenue?

blocks.content:
Topic: Campus second-hand textbook matching + AI search

**Problem**: Each term change creates many used books; manual search is time-consuming and info is fragmented.
**Audience**: Undergraduate students; decision-maker and user are the same.
**Unique solution**: Upload course codes to auto-match book lists; AI text search supports edition/language; one-tap mark after completion.
**MVP** (3 days): form intake (title/course/campus/price) → Google Sheet → search page (keyword + course code) → Telegram Bot for match notifications.
**Validation metrics**: ≥20 successful matches in week 1; W2 retention (return to find the next book) ≥30%; average match time ≤24 hours.
**Risks**: Cold start of supply/demand → cooperate with class reps/clubs; fraud → verify campus emails; privacy → display only necessary contact info.

items: Building too many features at once → keep MVP to 1–3 core features.
Relying on friends’ opinions without behavior data → prioritize real actions (sign-ups, orders, leaving contact).
Ignoring ongoing costs (servers, review, staffing) → estimate early and set free-tier quotas.

definitions.term: Q: I have no ideas—where should I start?
definitions.definition: Begin with a “problem diary”: for 7 straight days, record 1 inconvenience per day; generate 1–2 solutions per the Five Pathways, then rank using the scoring matrix.

definitions.term: Q: How do I avoid copying or overlapping with others?
definitions.definition: Focus on narrow contexts and process optimization. Even with incumbents, you can enter specific scenarios (e.g., campus, specific subjects, specific processes).

definitions.term: Q: When should I start coding?
definitions.definition: Prefer no-code/forms/community tools to validate transactions or matches first; consider development after demand stabilizes.

blocks.title: Summary
blocks.content: Innovation is not accidental inspiration; it is a repeatable daily process. Start with the quick-start version, refine with the structured version, and pair with the scoring matrix and smallest experiments to consistently turn observations into value.
